We see today’s news as a clear positive for Wirecard with SoftBank as new anchor shareholder in the company.
Furthermore, the strategic partnership that was also announced in addition to SoftBank’s investment in Wirecard is another positive for the operating business of Wirecard, in our view. Japan and South Korea were more or less still two white spots in Wirecard’s regional footprint.
The new partnership will enable the company to leverage its product portfolio in the two countries and hence to maintain/potentially even accelerate the strong organic growth momentum of the company.

BE11:20am

Softbank’s 5.6% investment through a convertible is clearly positive: Strategic access to Japan/South Korea – current coverage blank spots – and Softbank’s active support of business partnerships offsets dilution by far, in our view. We believe that access to Softbank’s own portfolio companies, including its 29% in Alibaba, 15% in Uber, c. 20% in Didi etc., visibly enhances operating prospects, driving upside to our already
strong 33% EPS CAGR 2019-22E, well offsetting dilution. At 19.3x PPA adj. P/E 2020E, dropping to 14.6x 2021E, the stock looks very attractive, in our view.

11:20 am

Buy reiterated – attractive multiples The shares trade at 19.3x PPA adjusted P/E 2020E, dropping to 14.6x 2021E. We consider this highly attractive in view of its steep discount to Adyen while at the same time the new co-operation should visibly accelerate growth prospects – already at a strong 33% EPS CAGR 2019-22E.

BE11:29am

Wirecard’s2018 innovation day left us feeling that there was no differentiated technology, an ecosystem without a platform, an app that was subscale (Boon) and a reliance on pre-paid cards, the likes of which are glorified coupon/paper ticket replacements. And Uber? Uber has never mentioned Wirecard in their 3,278 page full S-1 and Wirecard has never mentioned a deal or partnership with Uber in any filing document – ever (we did a meta search on all documents this am). We can see that across every single public filing from Wirecard, the name Uber has only ever once been mentioned. In the 2017 annual report, to help describe what the e-Travel segment means in a definition term; “This segment includes holidays booked online i.e. hotels, private and holiday flats and package tours, mobility services and travel tickets booked online i.e. flight bookings, rental cars, coach travel and rail travel, and ride sharing services such as Uber”. Uber’s primary payment partner is Adyen, as we have highlighted recently (plus a deal with Square).

So SoftBank has an advantageous financial structure through a CB rather than straight risk of equity. Why does Wirecard need $1B? The company is already sitting on $1B of net cash and has said the company is past the M&A phase of their strategy. Wirecard may get relief today but a return to fundamentals begins tomorrow; the Singapore police investigation is ongoing, the auditor’s comments on the FY annual report remains to be seen and the final legal report, if one exists, has not been disclosed. We still have more questions than answers, and so we still remain sellers of the stock.

Tom Dalgleish Less than before, Wayne

In line results as Primark’s margin rebound offset by sugar

US dollar, better buying and tight stock management, was offset by
weakness in sugar. Operating cash flow rose strongly amid lower working
capital needs. It proposed an interim dividend of GBPp12.05.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Associated British Foods’ (ABF) interim results statement confirms
the group’s FY outlook, which calls for adjusted EPS in line with
last year. The conversion of space growth to profit growth at
Primark continues to impress (profits +25%). Primark in the US is
performing strongly and should become profitable next year. The
incrementally more constructive outlook on Sugar should provide
a boost to consensus estimates for FY2020 operating profit as
higher sugar prices feed into FY2020 contracting. We reiterate our
‘Outperform’ rating.

BE11:38am

Sales for the 24 weeks ended March 2nd 2019 increased 1% year-on-year (yoy)
to £7.532m, +2% in constant currency, with adjusted EBIT -1% to £639m.
Adjusted EPS for the half-year was 61.1p; DPS +3% yoy to 12.05p. EBIT growth
was driven by growth in Primark, Grocery and Ingredients offset by the expected
decline in profit at AB Sugar. The group’s FY 2019 outlook remains unchanged –
adjusted EPS is expected to be in line with last year (Davy forecast EPS: 135.5p).

BE11:38am

Primark like-for-like (LFL) sales declined by 1.5% (UK: +0.6%). Divisional sales
increased 4.4% yoy to £3.360m, driven by selling space expansion. Operating
margin increased by 190bps yoy to 11.7% as a result of favourable FX and good
buying. Sales in the eurozone increased 5.3% yoy, driven by strong sales in
mainland Europe offset by negative LFL growth (-3.2%), which was in line with
expectations (driven by Germany). Primark in the US continues to trade strongly
with positive LFL growth in the half and a “much reduced operating loss”.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Sugar EBIT achieved a small profit of £1m (Davy: -£11m) as a result of
significantly lower EU prices that affected the group’s UK and Spanish sugar
businesses. Profits for the second half are expected to be in line with last year. A
reduction in the European crop area for the 2019-2020 season should provide
support to prices in the medium term. Davy forecasts operating profit for AB Sugar
to trough in FY2019 at £32m.

BE11:38am

Or Citi.

BE11:39am

1H results in-line and no change to FY EPS outlook as “in-line with
last year”. The £100m swing from Sugar largely to Retail is supportive for valuation
but the FX gains are now set to reverse for Retail. Conversely, action taken on
Sugar should start to bear rewards looking into FY20E. Unless there is more
positive news in the analyst meeting discussing the FY20E outlook, we would
expect the shares to drift slightly given the recent rally and no further upgrades.

You can have doubts about the corporate structure, as well as the clarity of related party stuff, but there's nothing specific in the results to add to the worry. Here's Barclays.

Excel Developer @waynej: that is how property booms get stoked.
11:44 am
BE11:45am

Boohoo’s P4 results are strong: Boohoo has accelerated nicely during P4 (a point of focus for bears in the last couple of quarters), PLT is broadly in line, Nasty Gal has accelerated and EBITDA margins are better than their guidance and consensus. Guidance for FY20 looks decent – 25-30% revenue growth is a bit below company consensus at c30% but they have historically been conservative so this isn’t a concern. We estimate the EBITDA margin guidance of around 10% would be c9.6% pre IFRS 16, a fraction better than company consensus at 9.4%. The capex guidance of £50-60m is better that expected. So overall it is hard to pick holes here.

We are Equal Weight the shares. Execution has been mightily impressive on this name and we haven’t been pointing to a negative surprise in the run up to these results. But strong delivery certainly validates the share price run. We feel valuation already prices in a fair bit on 2.1x cal 2020E EV/Sales and 23x EV/EBITDA with very high ROIC but with estimate momentum still on side, this isn’t crazy.

BE11:45am

And Investec.

BE11:45am

Adj. EBITDA ahead of market expectations; the company has finished FY19 with net cash of £190.7m, well ahead of
expectations of c. £130m. Full year guidance sales guidance for FY20 is in line with expectations and the P4 performance
(whilst small) supports management’s confident outlook. We see room for consensus PBT forecasts to creep up c.
+2/3%, closer to our top of the range forecasts.
Headline results
 FY19 Group sales £856.9m, +48% YoY (consensus: £845.3m), implying a satisfactory finish to the year with Group sales +50%
over P4 (cons: +37%) driven by sales at PLT and sustained strong performances in the ROE and US, up c.90% and 105%
respectively, as well as softer comparatives this time last year (group FY18 sales growth went from 100% in P3 to 67% in P4).
 Adj. EBITDA £84.5m, +49% YoY (consensus: £81m) with margin up 10bps at 9.9%, ahead of FY guidance of 9.25 – 9.75%.
 boohoo full year sales £434.6mm, +16%, implying sales also accelerated over P4, +25% (H1: +15%, P3: +15%) and above
expectations (P4 consensus: +17%). Importantly, gross margins appear to have seen further improvement over H2
(particularly in P4); we estimate they were up 230bps in H2 (H1: +110bps, Q3: +150bps) driven, we suspect, by improved
stock control following a soft comparative last year when markdown was high.
 Performance at PLT remains very strong, with sales maintaining momentum, up 76.5% over P4 (H1: 132%; P3: 95%) and again
ahead of expectations (P4 cons: +65%). Gross margins were more sober in H2: +40bps, following a less promotional H1 ahead of
the warehouse transition (H1: +250bps). Elsewhere, the sales performance at Nasty Gal remains strong, +96% for the full year.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Outlook & Valuation
 New guidance for FY20 has been issued, with FY sales growth expected to be +25% to +30%, which at this point in the year
is typically conservative (FY20 consensus: +30%). EBITDA margins are expected to be 10%+ (IFRS16 adjusted) and 9.5%
pre IFRS16 adjustments (FY20 consensus: 9.4%). Medium term sales guidance has been maintained at +25% with EBITDA
margin guidance of c. 10%, but capex is now likely to be £50-60m (consensus: £80-90m) with management identifying
flexibility with warehouse capacity.
 Following our recent notes (“Underpinning a 10% EBITDA margin” and “Further to go”), we continue to believe there is limited
risk to gross margins in the medium term, while warehousing efficiencies should offset potentially higher international
distribution costs. We also believe fears of PLT cannibalisation are overdone given that dual brand customers buy
incremental volumes while PLT’s higher price points benefit group cash gross profit per item. With earnings momentum
remaining positive, we think the shares deserve to re-rate back to prior levels.

wayneJ @Excel - I actually think it has been a play on interest rates having a 30 year down trend.....will be 'interesting' if it reverses....
BE11:46am

And RBC.

BE11:46am

Boohoo continues to perform well despite a challenging backdrop, in part owing to its highly promotional strategy and where it is in its growth cycle. However, Boohoo's ambition to be the best-in-class internet fashion retailer globally will come at a price, in our view. We therefore believe incremental investment in the business is a question of when, not if, to sustain high levels of growth. Boohoo now trades at CY19e 2.2x EV/Sales compared to 1.1x of ASOS and 1.5x of Zalando.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Pro Hastings, anti Direct Line and Saga.

Excel Developer @BE: thanks for editing.
BE11:51am

Upgrade Saga to Neutral (UW). Saga significantly reset expectations
with its recent results, and following a 50% share price decline in the last
month we revisit the outlook. We continue to see uncertainties: 1) high
leverage, set to peak at ~3.8x ND:EBITDA we estimate; 2) questions
surrounding the new 3 year product structure; and 3) lack of visibility on
sustainable margins. In our view evidence of delivery is required before
the shares substantially re-rate, however at current levels we also see
more limited downside risks. For this reason we move to Neutral.
 Downgrade Direct Line to Neutral (OW). Having outperformed peers
in the past 6 months and with limited upside to our valuation, we believe
there will be better opportunities to revisit Direct Line. Although we
continue to expect significant expense ratio improvement in the coming
years, this is likely to be fully offset by lower reserve releases and higher
attritional loss ratios, suggesting limited scope for earnings growth. We
also see the FCA market study as a potential risk, which if nothing else is
likely to preclude a further re-rating. We continue to prefer DLG to
Admiral (UW), given differences in balance sheet strength and valuation.
 How to position in UK non-life. Overall we have a cautious view of the
UK motor sector, as although we expect pricing to improve during 2019,
claims inflation continues to run in the +3-5% range. We see Hastings as
relatively well positioned here, but in the wider UK non-life sector
continue to see a more positive outlook for the Lloyd’s companies,
where we rate Beazley and Hiscox OW.

Bluesky21 Is JPM not a bit too relaxed about the next round of premium deflation?

Nately @Bluesky21 - Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Facebook, Alphabet... Think I'd rather buy SMT (but I won't).

BE11:52am

Hastings in our view possesses a number of key attributes that have helped
establish Admiral as a best-in-class motor insurer, yet it trades a discount
to peers. This in our view is partly a reflection of its leverage to the UK
motor cycle (challenging at this point), but over time we see scope for a rerating,
alongside continued market share gains. In particular we highlight:
1) its expense ratio advantage; 2) its competitiveness on new business
(particularly relevant ahead of the FCA market study); and 3) its
underwriting track record, which we see as increasingly strong. Overall
given the relative valuation we see a positive risk/reward, for what in our
view will be a long-term winner in the sector. We increase our Dec-19 TP
to 265p (was 240p), and upgrade to Overweight.

Q1 performance was strong across the board, with production beating the guidance for the quarter and the all-in sustaining costs (AISC) hitting the lower end of the guidance range. The first half of this year is an important period for the business, with steady operational delivery around guidance being required to rebuild investor confidence following a difficult2018 for the operations. It is therefore pleasing to see performance come out at the betterend of the guidance range, with further momentum in quarterly production rates anticipatedthrough the year.

BE12:01pm

● Outlook: The company has stated that it remains on track for 2019 guidance of 490-520koz
of production at an AISC of $890-950/oz. The quarterly production profile is expected to
gain momentum through the year as open pit grades rise and the operating improvements
in the underground continue to deliver tighter control on dilution. That said, it would
probably be unfair to expect the AISC to fall from here, as the group has already stated that it
will sequence sustaining capital spend to align with the strength of production. We therefore
expect the uptick in spend to offset the unit cost benefit of rising production.
● Longer-term visibility is coming: The company is looking to release longer-term guidance
for 2020 and 2021 during the current quarter (Q2 2019). We would expect this to be well
received by the market, as the uncertainty about the outlook for grades following the
